Award.AwardTitle: From Dualism to Integration Investigating Development of Engineering Students' Social and Technical Perceptions

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
From Dualism to "Integration":Investigating Development of Engineering Students' Social and Technical Perceptions

Engineering education provides students with foundational technical knowledge and skills, as well as a sense of engineering identity. Yet as prior sociological studies suggest, most engineering degree programs place primary emphasis on technical topics, which tends to marginalize or exclude the social dimensions of engineering identity and work practices. This investigation responds to such research by exploring engineering students' cognitive perceptions of their social and technical worlds, the relationship between their perceptions of these two domains, and how such perceptions develop. This study employs an embedded, sequential mixed-methods approach, which includes an interpretive phenomenological analysis of how engineering students integrate and/or split their social and technical perceptions of engineering ability and identity. This qualitative portion of the study is preceded and supported by data from instruments that probe how students perceive and orient to their social and technical worlds.

The proposed investigation builds on literature from the social sciences, psychology, and engineering education by examining students' technical and social perceptions. It fills a gap in the existing research by investigating the cognitive models that undergird how students develop the integrated, sociotechnical perception needed to address the broad, global challenges facing engineers today. This project lays key foundations for reforming curricula to enhance the development of these perceptive abilities and associated skills within engineering education. This investigation has potential for broad impact by informing engineering educators of critical experiences that shape the technical and social perceptions of students. The findings can be used to develop curricula, assessment techniques, and pedagogical strategies that better enable educators to guide students into a coherent integration of their social and technical perceptions. Such integration can cultivate engineers with enhanced capabilities who can tackle the engineering problems marked by sociotechnical complexity, including the "grand challenges" that face society. Integrating social and technical perceptions within the curriculum also has potential to enhance diversity in engineering by appealing to underrepresented groups of students who may be drawn toward more integrated, sociotechnical approaches to engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background/Context: Engineers are increasingly called upon to address challenges that are socially complex, profoundly affecting the everyday lives of individuals. However, engineering programs are traditionally designed to teach technical concepts to engineering students rather than training students to understand how their work is affected by social contexts. Furthermore, there is little understanding as to how engineering students come to understand who they are as engineers while they are being trained in primarily technical degree programs.

Purpose: To address these gaps, this project had three main goals: (1) develop a clear understanding of how engineering students develop their identities as engineers, especially in relation to social and technical dimensions of these identities, (2) generate a theory to explain how students manage their thinking in the technical and social features of their identities, and (3) identify how engineering degree programs create activities that shape their identities as engineers, especially in relation to social and technical dimensions.

Approach: In order to get a detailed picture of how thinking about identity changes throughout the engineering degree program, we conducted this project in three phases. In the first phase, we interviewed seven individuals on two occasions as they graduated from engineering degree programs. In the second phase, we interviewed four engineering students on three occasions as they transitioned from their first-year of college into their second year, when they began to take engineering-specific coursework. In the third phase, we interviewed seventeen individuals on two separate occasions as they transitioned from the second to the third years of their degree programs.

Results: We conducted deep analysis of the interview transcripts to provide a detailed picture of how engineering students come to see themselves as engineers. Our findings showed that, on one hand, the participants of the study saw themselves as the ideal image of a primarily technical engineer. But these same students also tended to distance themselves from this image, especially if fulfilling this image went against their desires to be socially connected to others in their lives. Our findings also pointed to how, in relation to the general population, the study participants committed to their careers early in their overall development as individuals. However, as they transitioned to their careers, they tended to explore features of their identities that are not related to their work, such as personal interests, social relationships, or other features of their identities that they did not nurture during their college years.

Conclusions: Overall, the extensive data analysis revealed that engineering majors and early-career engineers are driven to understand who they are beyond their professional roles as engineers. The findings of this project can profoundly impact how we understand early-career professionals as whole persons, beyond their career roles. By recognizing how engineering professionals live integrated lives with their personal experience, for example, workplaces may develop programming to allow for guided exploration when onboarding new hires. Furthermore, this study makes visible the importance of the role of engineering institutions and workplaces in preparing whole professionals that are personally motivated to execute high-quality work as a function of their personal identities.
